Clostridium frigoriphilum is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Antarctica. This species is known for its ability to thrive in cold environments, with an optimal growth temperature range of 4-15°C.

C. frigoriphilum is a psychrophilic (cold-loving) bacterium, capable of growing at temperatures as low as 0°C. It can metabolize a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, and can produce various fermentation products such as acetate, butyrate, and hydrogen.

The spores of C. frigoriphilum are believed to play a crucial role in its survival and dispersal in the harsh Antarctic environment, where it can withstand freezing temperatures and other environmental stresses. This unique adaptation makes C. frigoriphilum an interesting subject for research in the field of microbial ecology and biotechnology, particularly in applications related to cold-active enzymes and bioremediation in cold regions.
